issue.title: CosmosDB Point Read not taking into account partition and id

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
## File a bug
The bug: I'm trying to perform point read using `Find()`. From the debug logging it appears not to use the `partition` and `id` I've configured when using `Find()` or `FindAsync()`.

**This is a different bug from** https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/27679 **as there the ReadItem was not executed and instead it used SQL. Here it is executed.**

Using local CosmosDB emulator (using CosmosDB in Azure yields same results):
```
Information: Reading resource '?' item from container 'MyContainer' in partition '?'.
Information: Executed ReadItem (6.0212 ms, 1 RU) ActivityId='95262ba5-972f-497b-9846-6eb223413bb1', Container='MyContainer', Id='?', Partition='?'
```
It does find the correct record and return it with `1 RU` which indicates it used a point read. So it is more cost effective than a `.Single()` which uses `> 2.3 RU`. It makes me think it actually did use the `partition` and `id` but they were incorrectly logged. I Think this because point read _REQUIRES_ partition key to be used as stated [here](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/cosmosdb/point-reads-versus-queries/). But because the debug logging it states they are `?` it makes me think reads could be faster if they were picked up correctly.

As in the Microsoft Docs it is stated that it should use those. From the docs:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/what-is-new/ef-core-6.0/whatsnew#diagnostics 
```
info: 8/30/2021 14:53:39.326 CosmosEventId.ExecutingReadItem[30101] (Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Database.Command)
      Reading resource 'Isosceles' item from container 'Shapes' in partition 'TrianglesPartition'.
info: 8/30/2021 14:53:39.330 CosmosEventId.ExecutedReadItem[30103] (Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Database.Command)
      Executed ReadItem (1 ms, 1 RU) ActivityId='3c278643-4e7f-4bb2-9953-6055b5f1288f', Container='Shapes', Id='Isosceles', Partition='TrianglesPartition'
```

### Include your code

Context
```C#
    public class CosmosContext : DbContext
    {
        public DbSet<ItemModel> Items { get; set; }

        public CosmosContext(DbContextOptions<CosmosContext> options) : base(options)
        {
            
        }

        protected override void OnModelCreating(ModelBuilder modelBuilder)
        {
            modelBuilder.Entity<ItemModel>(builder =>
            {
                builder
                    .ToContainer("MyContainer")
                    .HasNoDiscriminator()
                    .HasPartitionKey(x => x.Category)
                    .HasKey(x => new { x.Category, x.id});
            });

            base.OnModelCreating(modelBuilder);
        }
    }
```
Model
```C#
    public class ItemModel
    {
        public string id { get; set; }

        public string Title { get; set; }

        public bool Done { get; set; }

        public string Category { get; set; }


        public ItemModel(string id, string title, bool done, string category)
        {
            this.id = id;
            Title = title;
            Done = done;
            Category = category;
        }
    }
```
Code calling the context. With `id: axeholding32` and `Category: Chores`
```C#
        [HttpGet]
        [Route("{category}/{id}")]
        public async Task<IActionResult> Get(string category, string id)
        {
            var item = await _context.Items.FindAsync(category, id);

            return new JsonResult(item);
        }
```
code registering EF and Cosmos
```C#
builder.Services.AddCosmos<CosmosContext>(
    "connectionstring",
    databaseName: "MyDb");
```
The data in CosmosDB
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17491881/162201045-1f476f03-c21a-4d11-bad1-f53de927e4f3.png)


### Include stack traces
From using local CosmosDB emulator:
```
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Database.Command: Information: Reading resource '?' item from container 'MyContainer' in partition '?'.
Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Database.Command: Information: Executed ReadItem (6.0212 ms, 1 RU) ActivityId='95262ba5-972f-497b-9846-6eb223413bb1', Container='MyContainer', Id='?', Partition='?'
```

### Include verbose output

Please include `--verbose` output when filing bugs about the `dotnet ef` or Package Manager Console tools.

Use triple-tick fences for tool output. For example:

```
C:\Stuff\AllTogetherNow\FiveOh>dotnet ef dbcontext list --verbose
Using project 'C:\Stuff\AllTogetherNow\FiveOh\FiveOh.csproj'.
...
Using assembly 'CosmosTest'.
Using startup assembly 'CosmosTest'.
Using application base 'C:\Users\Wille\source\repos\sigr-negotiation-spike\02_Backend\Sigr1\Sigr1\CosmosTest\bin\Debug\net6.0'.
Using working directory 'C:\Users\Wille\source\repos\sigr-negotiation-spike\02_Backend\Sigr1\Sigr1\CosmosTest'.
Using root namespace 'CosmosTest'.
Using project directory 'C:\Users\Wille\source\repos\sigr-negotiation-spike\02_Backend\Sigr1\Sigr1\CosmosTest\'.
Remaining arguments: .
Finding DbContext classes...
Finding IDesignTimeDbContextFactory implementations...
Finding application service provider in assembly 'CosmosTest'...
Finding Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting service provider...
Using environment 'Development'.
Using application service provider from Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting.
Found DbContext 'CosmosContext'.
Finding DbContext classes in the project...
CosmosTest.EfCore.CosmosContext
```

### Include provider and version information

EF Core version: 6.0.3
Database provider: Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.Cosmos 6.0.3
Target framework: .NET 6
Operating system: Windows 10
IDE: VS 2022 17.0.5

body:
Same issue here... tried to avoid using Guid as Key in favor of string instead in case of conversion issues, no changes.
Also tried to isolates my entity types into distinct container and removed discriminator to get it out of query, still no point read.

**Edit**
Looks like the issue is related to a sub entity, configured as default as a owned entity based on convention, while my root/parent entity is configured through `IEntityTypeConfiguration`. As soon as I remove any reference to sub entity in my model from root entity, then it works as expected!

issue.title: EF Core does not support point to read queries

repository.name: EntityFramework.Docs
repository.description: Documentation for Entity Framework Core and Entity Framework 6

issue.body:
Currently due to an [open bug](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/issues/27679) (without a ETA commitment) EF Core does not support [Point Reads](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/optimize-cost-reads-writes#point-reads)

This has a signifficant impact on cost and hence should be documented in limitations. I've seen teams investing days into EF Core with Cosmos DB just to find out the hard way and wasting time migrating to native client

The current lack of transparency is damaging the reputation of EF Core (== slow) 


---
#### Document Details

⚠ *Do not edit this section. It is required for learn.microsoft.com ➟ GitHub issue linking.*

* ID: a102d2e4-41d0-4619-a463-3e3862311a01
* Version Independent ID: a80b35f2-09dc-da67-df83-253ca5fd78cb
* Content: [Azure Cosmos DB Provider - Limitations - EF Core](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/providers/cosmos/limitations)
* Content Source: [entity-framework/core/providers/cosmos/limitations.md](https://github.com/dotnet/EntityFramework.Docs/blob/main/entity-framework/core/providers/cosmos/limitations.md)
* Product: **entity-framework**
* Technology: **entity-framework-core**
* GitHub Login: @AndriySvyryd
* Microsoft Alias: **avickers**

body: The workaround for the original issue is to type the `Id` property as `string`.

issue.title: Cosmos: use Point-Read when the key is a Guid.
